bboxes.raw_text:
Nearly every phase of scouting
activity will be represented in
ESQ exhibits at the annual Scout
ing Exposition at the Arizona
State Fairgrounds, April II
and 10.


Cub Scouts, Boy Scouts and
Explorer Scouts from eight to
lS years of age from the Theo-
dore Roosevelt Council of the Boy
Scouts of America will take part
in the huge show. More than a
third of the 1896 boys and
$500 adults working in the oO7
scout groups in the council will
participate.


A total Of 3lS subject CLASH

fications are open to the boys
in which they can create an ex-
hibit. A general group, collec-
tons and crafts are open to Cub
Scouts, totaling 90 categories.
General groups and merit badge
subjects with l40 classifications
are listed under Boy Scouts and
specially activities totaling 81
subjects are open to Explorers.


Admission to the 1864 EXPOSE
ton will be ST. for adults. All
children accompanied by adults
will be admitted free.


Proceeds raised will provide
more Boy Scout camp facilities
in Arizona.
Scouting Exposition to be in April

Douglass of the Negro Abolonsts described his
beginnings in the opening pages of his NARTVE "n Talbot
County Shore State of Maryland Easton without
any fault Of my born and the first
childhood suppose myself have February 1917


My only recolecdons of my mother few hasy visits in
the night foot Of father knew nothing hardly became
thinking thing when first learned to hate slavery


At of 10 Frederick learned read little from his
mistress until her husband angy interered In his early teens
in spelling we'll scriptures until white broke up
warning him to "try to be another Nat Turner


his for tanning who enjoyed the
reputation Of being rstra hand breaking young Negroes
The first week under Covey he ogged severely that ne
forever the upon his back BY resisting subsequent
administer beatngs, Frederick found that when
a slave be f1ogged, he is than half free.'


On September g. 1885, the Of H. Frederick escaped to
New York disguised sailor He married free Negro girl
and moved New Bedford Massachusetts, where William c.
Coffin the Abodonis heard him speak, Coffin invited Frederick
tell his anslavery convention In l841 When ne
finished Lloyd Garrison cried ave been listening


thing piece of property man7 The crowd answered.
IA mani A mani"


day Frederick Douglass became public figure. He
Collins Garrison and Wendell Phillips He attacked
by Boston, Harrisburg and Indiana Enroute Europe
in 845 Soterners threatened to throw Douglass overheard
talk he made aboard ship He leced In England for years
only slavery suffrage While there he
raised enough purchase his freedom and establish news
his to the United States.


847 Rochester, Douglass founded the North STAR Its
fright is of Truth is of no color God is the
Father Of ALL and all Brethren Douglass later changed
the name O Frederick Douglass Paper.


week. in the crucial decades before the Civil War,
Douglass preaching pleading Long
Lincoln Douglass said the Negro ne1tricaby
the War couldn't be fought ended without coming
grips with the issue Of slavery.


After Emancipation Douglass turned his mind Reconstruction
He demanded ballots and land for the freedmen In 1885, he de-
nounced Negroes socaed spendous fraud


abandoned the Negro left him In
law, free; in fact, slave" he said.


In period Marshal
District Columbia and Minister Of Haiti but he continued
Of Negroes His battle Age Agitatel


In February 1885, he died Anacosa Heights Washington D. c.

Formal action necessary for
the Salt River Project to make
voluntary contributions in lieu
of taxes to the state, counties,
cities, towns, and school districts
in which Project electrical facil-
tiles and properties are located,
has been completed, announced
Victor /. Corbell, president of the
Salt River Project.

He said the permissive legis-
lation enacted last year by the
State Legislature provided for
certain conditions before the
Project could make voluntary
contributions. Included were ap-
proval by the Secretary of Inter-
Tor and notification of the Pro-
ject's election to make contribu-
lions to the affected county as
SCISSORS each year.

Fred Dryer, Jr., %. son Of
Mr.. and Mrs. Fred Dryer, 2l43
E. Corona, is stationed at Fort
Polk, La.


He was indicted on Jan. %.


Fred graduated from Julian
Elementary School andhe attend
ed South Mountain High School.
